title: Wednesday, 11th July, 2018

BE11:12am

Trade tensions escalated overnight as US released a list of Chinese goods where it was looking to impose c.10% of tariffs on up to US$200bn of additional imports. This comes after US imposed tariffs on US$34bn of Chinese imports (WSJ). Chinese commerce ministry said that it would retaliate against any US imports. China and commodity markets which had calmed down after last week resumed their downturn this morning with China indices down c.2% and commodities down anywhere between 2-4% with zinc again being the big underperformer. Yuan resumed its slide too - down 40bps; another interesting headline which could indicate further yuan volatility; China’s FX regulator said that corporates should hedge themselves to protect against yuan fluctuations which could potentially mean that yuan likely remains volatile in the near term (

BE11:12am

While there is a 2 month comment period between now and the final
imposition of the tariffs - this is likely to hurt the already weak investor
sentiment towards commodities / miners.

Grouchmonkey Morning
BE11:12am

Oui.

11:12 am
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 313.90, down 13.05 (-3.99%), High: 319.15, Low: 310.35, Volume: 21.55m
SoS Including EU ones according to Tim Martin this morning (thats a request for spoons)

BE11:13am

And Nomura.

BE11:14am

After a relatively calm weekend following
the initial round of US tariffs and China’s response on 6 July, we view this as a significant
escalation in the US-China trade dispute.
On the one hand, the Office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR) was
likely to release this list at some point after President Trump threatened this sort of
escalation. We expected some response in the wake of China’s reaction to the first
round of US tariff increases. However, the release of this list, only four days after the
initial round of tariffs took effect, indicates that trade protectionism may escalate beyond
the initial round of tariffs imposed last week.
The initial round of tariffs, at 25% targeting $50bn of Chinese imports, focused primarily
on capital goods, mitigating any potential impact on consumers. However, the new list,
targeting $200bn with a 10% tariff, is almost equally split between capital and consumer
goods (Figure 1). Thus, if these tariffs do indeed take effect, there would likely be a
larger impact on consumers than in the initial round. Looking at more detailed categories,
however, machinery and electrical equipment remains the most heavily targeted group,
consistent with the administration’s approach of taking aim at certain machinery and
electrical equipment outlined in Beijing’s “Made in China 2025” plan

11:14 am
BE11:14am

While the number of products targeted in the new list is substantially higher than in the initial round, the impact on inflation will likely be muted, in our opinion. We previously estimated that the direct impact of a 10% tariff on all Chinese imports (about $500bn) would be roughly 20bp on consumer prices. By that measure, should the tariffs announced today materialize, it would result in upward pressure of about 8bp on consumer prices. The impact on business confidence and financial conditions, however, could be larger. These developments do pose some downside risk to our forecast.

BE11:14am

See. Tariffs are bad. There we have it.

Full year guidance was reiterated with the company expecting revenue declines of 6-9% and EBITDA margin of ~37%. Management said that due to initial challenges in the integration of the HPE Software assets, the company is running 1 year behind schedule. Management now expects to stabilize revenue declines and reach mid-40s EBITDA margins by 2020.

BE11:25am

Micro Focus is trading on 8.1x calendarised 2019e EV/EBITDA versus the global software sector on an average 17x, with much of the differential due to lower revenue growth prospects, higher debt ratios, as well as recent volatility.

Problem 1: market share and pricing of Suboxone film are crashing due to Dr Reddy's going with an at-risk generic launch, as we covered in depth a month or so ago.

BE11:30am

Problem 2: doctors don't seem keen to write scrips for the one-a-month injection that Indivior needs to replace those lost Suboxone sales.

BE11:31am

Statement refers to "friction" from doctors and payers, which I think means resistance.

11:31 am

Where does this leave Sublocade? We don't know.

Stock Anything Sky?
BE11:33am

Company retains long-term targets. But might it be that people addicted to painkillers and/or heroin don't always get the top-of-the-range branded drug when there's a passable generic on offer?

Grouchmonkey I liked the statement from Burford. Paraphrase as "we have no idea what our assets are worth, so don't expect us to correct the projections of analysts who have no idea either"
BE11:33am

Here's Stifel, which is the most readable and non-technical of the sellside here.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

The launch of Sublocade was always expected to raise challenges given it is a controlled substance that requires administration by a caregiver in the doctor's office rather than the typical psychiatrist writing a prescription. That said, the size of the market for opioid use disorder treatments and the clear benefits of a once monthly treatment such as Sublocade were expected to lead to a strong uptake. Encouragingly, Indivior has received better than expected reimbursement by private payers with coverage standing at greater than 55% of US covered lives at this point. The company remains confident of achieving its target of c.80% coverage by the end of 2018. However, difficulties in distribution and reimbursement have impacted physician willingness to prescribe. For example, one of the main potential impediments mentioned at our KOL hosted lunch in May 2018, was psychiatrist ability and readiness to store scheduled medicines on site. Indivior noted that improvement in patient throughput remains gradual. We are therefore reducing our Sublocade forecasts, expecting sales of $31m in 2018 (previously $94m). Indivior still expects Sublocade to achieve peak sales of

$1bn. We continue to forecast peak sales of Sublocade of c.$960m but have delayed this being achieved by a year to 2022E.

BE11:36am

So ..... 2018 EPS down 39% to 10 cents.

BE11:36am

2019 moves from a 27 cent profit to a 4 cent loss.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

2020 moves from 57 cents to 20 cents.

BE11:37am

These are massive downgrades. Though Stifel still rates this thing 440p on a DCF.

BE11:38am

BE11:40am

The most concerning aspect of the statement regarding 2018
guidance is the commentary on Sublocade launch, where uptake appears to be slower than consensus expectations (2018 guidance of $25-50m vs consensus $86m and Citi $49m). Despite guidance of greater than $1bn peak sales being reiterated, the market will likely have concerns, given the “friction” in distribution and reimbursement. We have previously published a scenario (Risk-Reward Balanced After Recent Run. Downgrade to Neutral. May-18) where $600m in Sublocade peak sales vs our estimate of $1.1bn impacts our base case valuation of 500p by around 160p. Even before this news, we viewed the original 2018 revenue guidance of $1,130m-$1,170m as ambitious (Citi $1,060) given the trends in the opioid market. The latest week’s IMS data (see Figure 2) do not show Suboxone film generic (although the data is from the week when Dr Reddy’s may have launched on the Friday), but shows some loss to generic tablets. We look with interest at the next data point this Friday. We will revise our scenario analysis once we know the outcome of the preliminary injunction hearing, expected at the end of this week.

Here's Liberum, which is shop.

BE11:50am

Safestyle’s trading update contains the good news that order intake has now stabilised following disruption from a very aggressive new market entrant, and that staff numbers are now starting to be rebuilt. The bad news is that activity levels are at a lower level and margins have suffered more than originally expected. This has led us to reduce expected PBT from a £4m profit to a £3m loss, but we are confident in new management’s ability to restore profits. The balance sheet is now only expected to have a small net cash position at year end, but facilities are now in place, and we do not expect these to be needed without a further deterioration in trading. We have cut our target price from 60p to 40p to anticipate the likely stock market reaction, but we are starting to see significant upside on a two year view if recovery takes hold, noting that the shares would only be on 2x peak earnings at that level.

Pharma @Soundbuy, and opaque. No idea what a window should cost, even as a ball-park.
andyalan10 Is there a big opaque window market?

Paper Chase @andyalan10 There is. "Bricks", I think they're called?
BE11:51am

SafeGlaze, that was it. And there's a legal action live so we can't say much.

BornCynic That happens a lot - locally Pearce signs management left to set up Blaze Neon when they realised how much money could be made out of producing signs.
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Back to Liberum.

BE11:51am

We have cut our target price from 60p to 40p in anticipation of an adverse market reaction to a further reduction in estimates. However, new management has achieved stabilisation and is working hard to improve momentum; and, we believe that the shares could rise to 80p on a two year view (10x PER 2020E) if the stock market starts to have confidence in the 2020E estimates. We also highlight that at 40p the shares would only trade at around 2x peak earnings, suggesting very considerable upside if management can successfully rebuild the business to previous levels of activity. Our twelve month target price represents how we believe the stock market will value the shares in the short term (looking at an amalgam or PER, EV/EBITDA and FCF yield multiples). We keep our Hold rating while we wait for sequentially improving sales and margins.

Mr Diamond nonsense statement, "cut our target price from 60p to 40p to anticipate the likely stock market reaction"

Paper Chase @Kathryn I suppose it must be a portmanteau of cumulative synergy so, er, I have no idea.
Excel Developer @Kathryn : 'cum' is Latin for 'with' so cumsynergy = with-synergy. The with-synergy price is the analyst's target price with synergies.

An unidentified investor sold a stake worth approximately $160 million in Playtech Plc about two weeks before the U.K. software company reported a profit warning that sent the stock tumbling, people familiar with the matter said.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc.’s trading desk began to market the stake on June 14, the people said, asking not to be named as the details aren’t public. The seller was a U.S. hedge fund, two of the people said.

We lower our 2019E EPS estimate by 35% and reduce our price target to 550p (was 980p). With just 4% potential upside to our price target, we downgrade Playtech to Neutral, We think a cost-saving programme announcement is likely, but that the risk of further attrition in Asia, regulatory change in Italy, a deflationary
renegotiation of the Ladbrokes Coral (LCL) contract, and poor organic growth momentum will continue to weigh on the shares

There is no reason to believe that Playtech will not be able to compete with Skywind, but we find it unusual that Skywind has been able to use the “Playtech S” brand name. This is particularly concerning given Playtech’s brand name is highly valued in Asia.
